block1_text.eng: These charts are 10 by 10 arrays of numbers in order. Typically, they can either go from 1 to 100 or from 0 to 99.

block1_text.eng: An acute angle is an angle whose measure is more than 0 degrees and less than 90 degrees.

rows.block1_text: An acute angle is an angle whose measure is more than 0 degrees and less than 90 degrees.

block1_text.eng: An acute triangle is a triangle with three acute angles, that is, all its angles are less than 90 degrees.

rows.block1_text: An acute triangle is a triangle with three acute angles, that is, all its angles are less than 90 degrees.

block1_text.eng: An angle is a geometric figure created by two lines, line segments, or rays meeting at a point. Note that when lines or line segments cross, as in the illustrations on the left side, they form four angles.

rows.block1_text: An angle is a geometric figure created by two lines, line segments, or rays meeting at a point. Note that when lines or line segments cross, as in the illustrations on the left side, they form four angles.

block1_text.eng: This measure is the size of an angle, usually measured in degrees in the earlier school years. 90 degrees (written 90°) is the size of an angle formed at the corner of most pieces of paper. 180 degrees (180°) is the measure of a straight angle, and 360 degrees (360°) is the measure of one full turn.

block1_text.eng:
* The measure of an **acute angle** is more than 0 degrees and less than 90 degrees.
* The measure of a **right angle** is 90 degrees. It is the size of the corner of most pieces of paper.
* The measure of an **obtuse angle** is larger than 90 degrees and less than 180 degrees.

block1_text.eng: This is the number of units that are needed to cover a region. It is usually measure in square units basic on a standard length – such as square inches, square feet, square centimeters, or square meters.

block2_text.eng:
Here are the area formulas for a few standard shapes:
* Rectangle  – The product of its length and width.
* Triangle – The product of the length of one side times the height from that side.
* Parallelogram  – The product of the length of one side times the height from that side.
* Kite – Half the product of the legths of its two diagonals.

block1_text.eng: This is an ordered collection of objects presented in rectangular form. Examples include a collection of dots, squares, or numbers.

block1_text.eng:
An operation is associative if the value of an expression involving that operation does not change value depending on how grouping is done in the expression. To make it more memorable, you can say that an operation is associative if it doesn't matter how the numbers associate (group up) with each other. In general, associativity is a bit too abstract for young children. **Examples** * Addition is associative.
(2 + 3) + 4 = 2 + (3 + 4) * Multiplication is associative.
(2 x 3) x 4 = 2 x (3 x 4). * Subtraction is not associative.
(8 - 3) - 1 ≠ 8 - (3 - 1) * Division is not associative.
(24 / 12) / 2 ≠ 24 / (12 / 2) is 4. One way to see that multiplication is associative is to notiice that it does not matter which way you calculate the volume of a box. You can take the area of any of the sides and multiply that area by the height, and you always get the same volume. See also: **properties of operations.**

See also: **volume.**

block1_text.eng:
A cardinal number is the count or size of a collection. This is in contrast to an ordinal number, which describes the relative position. 

**Example:** You might have the second in a collection of four objects. Four is the cardinal number and second is the ordinal number.

See also: **numbers – types.**

block1_text.eng: A chord is a line segment whose endpoints lie on a circle. The circle illustrated below is shown with two chords. The chord that goes through the center of the circle is called a diameter.

rows.block1_text: A chord is a line segment whose endpoints lie on a circle. The circle illustrated below is shown with two chords. The chord that goes through the center of the circle is called a diameter.

block1_text.eng: A circle is the set of all points in a plane that are the same distance from a point called its **center**. That distance is called the **radius** of the circle.

block2_text.eng:
This meaning of "radius," which refers to a number, can be confused with the other meaning, which refers to a geometric object (a line segment from the center to a point on the circle). However, this is rarely a problem in that the first meaning is a number whereas the second is a geometric object.

Some people incorrectly refer to the region inside the circle as being part of the circle.

See also **shapes – 2d.**

block1_text.eng:
The circumference is the length once around a circle.

Formulas for the circumference are:
* pi times the diameter
* twice pi times the radius

block1_text.eng:
A common factor (or common divisor) of a set of integers is an integer that divides evenly into all of them.

Finding common factors is useful for finding equivalent fractions.

**Example** 3 is a common factor of 6 and 9. 4 is a common factor of 12, 8, and 28.

block1_text.eng:
A common multiple of a set of number is a number that is a multiple of all of them.

Finding a common multiple is useful for finding a common denominator for a group of fractions.

**Example** 24 is a common multiple of 8 and 12. 60 is a common multiple of 12, 15, and 20.

block1_text.eng:
An operation is commutative if the order in an expression involving the operation does not change its value. **Examples** * Addition is commutative.
2 + 4 = 4 + 2 * Multiplication is commutative.
2 x 4 = 4 x 2 * Subtraction is not commutative.
4 - 2 ≠ 2 - 4 * Division is not commutative.
4 / 2 ≠ 2 / 4 Students typically find it natural that addition is commutative. You can further convince them of it by showing them a pile of 3 objects next to a pile of 2 objects. You have 5 objects altogether whether you count the 3 objects and then count 2 more, or you count the 2 objects and then count 3 more.

block2_text.eng: Use a rectangle to demonstrate that multiplication is commutative. As an example, create a 2 by 3 rectangle made up of 6 squares. If you take that picture and look at it one way, you have 2 rows of 3 squares. If you turn that same rectangle a quarter turn, you now have 3 rows of 2 squares.

block1_text.eng: Compensation can be used to make some addition or subtraction calculations easier.

block2_text.eng:
For addition, a simpler problem is created by taking away a portion of one number and adding it to the other. For example, 8 + 7 can be turned into the much easier problem
(8 + 2) + (7 - 2) = 10 + 5. The 7 gives 2 to the 8 to make use of how easy it is to work with 10s.

block3_text.eng:
For subtraction, a simpler problem is created by adding or taking away the same amount from both numbers. This maintains the distance between the two numbers. 

For example, 13 – 8 can be turned into 15 – 10 by adding 2 to both numbers.

Similarly, 13 – 8 can be turned into 10 – 5 by subtracting 3 from both numbers. This latter problem is typically easier as the number bonds for 10 are learned early.

block1_text.eng: These numbers are the positive integers. Their name comes from the idea that these are the numbers that a child typically counts when starting at 1. The natural numbers are usually defined to be the same as the counting numbers.

rows.block1_text: These numbers are the positive integers. Their name comes from the idea that these are the numbers that a child typically counts when starting at 1. The natural numbers are usually defined to be the same as the counting numbers.

block1_text.eng: **Counting on** is a way of counting a group of objects by treating a portion of them as one unit whose size is already known.

block2_text.eng:
**Example:** Suppose you have 3 objects and 2 objects. You could use counting on for the seven objects by starting at 3 for the 3 known objects, and then counting "4, 5" pointing one at a time at the other 2 objects. You could also start with the 2 objects and count "3, 4, 5" while counting the remaining 3 objects. Children should learn the strategy that it saves time to start Counting On using the larger group of objects first.

Being able to treat a group of objects as a unit is called **unitizing,** and it is an important developmental step.

block1_text.eng: When reading a story to someone, having a dialog or discussion with them about the story as you read each page is called dialogic reading. The kind of dialog that is appropriate is dependent on the listener's developmental level.

block2_text.eng:
If the child does not understand your words yet, use "Point and Describe" and do not expect a response. **Point** to items and actions and **describe** them to the child. Children are wonderful sponges of experiences and they will learn a great deal from this exposure.

If the child does understand some of what you are saying, use "Point, Describe, and Ask." The responses to your questions may be for the child to point or otherwise indicate an answer – they can say a lot without using words.

block3_text.eng:
Continue to use "Point, Describe, and Ask." This kind of reading you use can be broken into three levels.

1. **Simple questions** Ask basic direct questions referring to the current page, such as "Is the ball red?" or "Where is the cat?"
2. **More open-ended questions** Ask more complex questions such as "What is the bird doing?" or "Do you think that was fair?" Expand on the child's response to create further questions and discussion ideas. These questions will still be focused on the current page of the story.
3. **More sophisticated questions** These questions may discuss the narrative of the story, such as what has happened so far or what will happen next, or they may relate back to the child’s life or world, such as "Do you like it when it rains?" Also, ask questions about a character’s inner life, such as what the character is feeling and has the child ever felt like that. At this level, there should be much more give and take between you, and the child should be encouraged to put questions of their own into the dialogue.

block1_text.eng:
Diameter, similar to radius, has two meanings. It can refer to the geometric object which is a line segment that goes through the center of a circle and whose endpoints lie on the circle. It can also refer to the length of that line segment.

Here is a circle with two chords drawn in. Only the chord that goes through the center of the circle is a diameter.

block2_text.eng:
The diameter of a circle is twice as long as its radius.

See also **shapes – 2d.**

block1_text.eng:
When referring to subtraction, the difference of two numbers is how far apart they are. For example, the difference of 6 and 4 is 2 because they are 2 apart.

It can be subtle whether "difference" should be considered as having a signed value or not. Put another way, is the distance between the numbers being thought of in a directed sense or an absolute sense? 

The difference is usually considered to be a positive number, though the longer phrase "positive difference" can be used to emphasize that meaning. WIth that understanding, the difference of 6 and 4 is the same as the difference of 4 and 6, and is 2 in both cases. It is how far apart the two numbers are on the number line, without regard to the direction being traveled from one number to the other. 

Some would suggest that "difference" is another word for subtraction, and so the result can be negative.

block1_text.eng:
Multiplication is said to **distribute over addition.**

**Examples:** 
* 3 x (5 + 1) = (3 x 5) + (3 x 1)
* (5 + 1) x 3 = (5 x 3) + (1 x 3).

This quality can be demonstrated by considering the area of a 3 by 6 rectangle in two ways.

Mulitplication is also said to **distribute over subtraction** in a similar manner.

See also: **properties of operations.**

block1_text.eng:
One number is divisible by another if the second number divides evenly into the first. That is, the result of the division needs to be an integer.

People sometimes use "evenly divisible* to refer to this, but that phrase means the same things as simply saying "divisible."

**Example**
* 6 is divisible by 3 because 6 / 3 = 2.
* 6 is not divisible by 4 because 6 / 4 = 1 1/2.

As pictured below, the top row has even numbers that are divisible by 2 and can be split into two equal rows. The second row has odd numbers that are not divisible by 2, and they leave a remainder of 1 when split into two rows.

block1_text.eng: An edge is usually a straight line segment that forms part of the boundary of a polygon. An edge can also be called a **side.**

rows.block1_text: An edge is usually a straight line segment that forms part of the boundary of a polygon. An edge can also be called a **side.**

block1_text.eng:
An equal sign "=" is used to indicate that two expressions have the same value. For example, 2 x 3 = 4 + 2 asserts that the expression on the left side of the equal sign, 2 x 3, has the same value as the expression on the right side of the equal sign, 4 + 2.

**False Beliefs:** Some believe that an equal sign indicates that a value is beiing produced by one side of the equation, as in 4 + 2 = 6. This is not the case. The equal sign has no preferred side to it. Also, some people believe that one of the two sides of an equal sign should be a solitary number. This also need not be the case, and it is important to not leave children with this impression.

See also the entries for "equation" and "expression."

block1_text.eng:
Two events or outcomes are said to be equally likely if the probability of their occuring is the same.

This is an important concept in calculating probabilities. A misunderstanding of it or a lack of awareness of it can lead to confusion. For example, when you roll two six-sided dice, there are 36 equally likely combinations of how the two dice may roll. However, even though there are 11 possible sums for the two dice (2 through 12), those 11 possible sums are not equally likely – for example, 2 can only occur in one way as 1 + 1, while 4 can occur in 3 ways as 1 + 3, 2 + 2, and 3 + 1.

block1_text.eng:
An equation is given by having two expressions being compared using an equal sign.

**Examples:** 
* x + 3 = y - 2
* 42 - 7 = 33 + 2.

block1_text.eng: An estimate is an approximate count or answer for the size of something. It can be called an "educated guess" in that some ideas are being used to come up with an answer, so it is different from simply guessing.

block2_text.eng: Make a game of making estimates by challenging students to come up with a quick estimation for the size of a group of objects before they have time to count them. Then have them check their answers. This is great practice with quantities and comparisons.

block1_text.eng:
An even number is an integer that can be evenly divided by 2. When it is divided by 2, the remainder is 0. It is also an integer that can be split into two equal integer parts.

For positive whole numbers, even numbers are quantities of objects that can be shared evenly between two groups without the need for fractional parts.

block1_text.eng:
The expanded form of a multi-digit number, also called the "expanded notation" for it, expresses the number in terms of its place value. For example, 576 in expanded form is 500 + 70 + 6.

Expanded form is extremely useful in understanding place value and how it is involved in doing the four basic arithmetic operations.

block1_text.eng:
Just as 4 × 2 is a quick way to write 2 + 2 + 2 + 2, so 2<sup>4</sup> is a quick way to write 2 × 2 × 2 × 2. It’s much easier to say and understand the phrase “two to the fourth,” than to say “two times two times ... “ In 2<sup>4</sup> for example, the 2 is called the **base** and the 4 is called the **exponent** or **power.**

**Special Names:** The second power, 4<sup>2</sup> for example, can be said **four squared,** and the third power, 4<sup>3</sup> for example, can be said **four cubed.** Any other power, such as 2<sup>8</sup> is said **two to the eighth.**

The phrase "8 is a power of 2" refers to 8 being the third power of 2. The first few powers of 2 are 2, 4, 8, and 16.

block1_text.eng:
An expression is a representation of a quantity in numeric or algebraic form. This representation may involve numbers, variables, or operations. 

**Examples:** 
* 42
* x
* (413 + 82) / 17
* (x + 2) x y.

block1_text.eng: A face of a polyhedron is one of the polygons that makes up the surface of that polyhedron. For example, the faces of a cube are six squares.

rows.block1_text: A face of a polyhedron is one of the polygons that makes up the surface of that polyhedron. For example, the faces of a cube are six squares.

block1_text.eng:
A fact family is a group of four related calculations involving the structural connection between three numbers and two operations. Fact families make clear the interdepence between two operations, and they also make the learning of the associated math facts more efficient.

**Example – Add Subtract:** Use the connection between addition and subtraction to form this family of four facts: 2 + 4 = 6; 4 + 2 = 6; 6 - 2 = 4; and 6 - 4 = 2.

**Example – Multiply Divide:** Use the connection between multiplication and division to form this family of four facts: 2 x 4 = 8; 4 x 2 = 8; 8 / 2 = 4; and 8 / 4 = 2.

block2_text.eng:
Make triangles for fact families. These are great for demonstrating how the facts in a fact family are connected.

The illustration shows the fact family for 3 + 5 = 8; 5 + 3 = 8; 8 - 5 = 3; and 8 - 3 = 5 along the edges of the triangle.

block1_text.eng:
One number is said to be a factor of another if it divides it evenly, that is, when there is no remainder for the division.

**Examples:** 2 is a factor of 6 because 6 divided by 2 is exactly 3 with remainder 0. 2 is not a factor of 7 because 7 divided by 2 is 3 with a remainder of 1.

block1_text.eng:
In a mathematical expression, there are a few notational ways to separate and group a part of the expression. Such groups are always evaluated together first and then that value is combined with the rest of the expression. For example, (2 + 3) x 4 becomes 5 x 4.

The most common form of grouping is to use a pair of parentheses, a pair of square brackets, or (less commonly) a pair of curly braces. 

**Examples:**
* (2 + 3) x 5
* [(2 + 3) * 5] / 4
* {2 + 4} - 7.

Writing a fraction in vertical form, with a horizontal line between the top and bottom, causes the top half and bottom half of the fraction to be put into groups.

The argument in functional notation, such as f(2 + 4), is another example of grouping.

block1_text.eng:
A hexagon is a six-sided polygon. It is also a polygon with six angles.

The green hexagon on the left has six equal sides and six equal angles. It is called a **regular hexagon.** The brown hexagon on the right is not regular.

A horizontal object, such as a horizontal line, is one that goes parallel to and in the same direction as the horizon line.

In this illustration, lines AB and EF are horizontal lines, and they are parallel to each other. The line CD is a vertical line, and it is perpendicular to both line AB and line EF.

block1_text.eng: The hypotenuse is the side opposite the right angle in a right triangle. It is the longest of the three sides. The other two sides of a right triangle are called **legs.**

block1_text.eng: A hundreds chart is a 10 by 10 chart that has the numbers 1 to 100, or 0 to 99, increasingly in order going along its rows. The entries of consecutive rows will be 10 apart.

block1_text.eng:
An inequality is any relationship between two expressions that involves their possibly not having the same value. One way this can happen is if one is greater than, or possibly equal to, the other. Another way is simply saying that the two values are different.

**Examples:**
1. 2 is less than 4; 2 < 4
2. 2 is less than or equal to 4; 2 ≤ 4
3. 4 is less than or equal to 4; 4 ≤ 4
4. 5 is greater than 3; 5 > 3
5. 5 is greater than or equal to 3; 5 ≥ 3
6. 3 is greater than or equal to 3; 3 ≥ 3
7. 5 and 3 are different: 5 ≠ 3.

If equality is not being allowed, it is called a **strict inequality.** In these examples, (1), (4), and (7) are examples of strict inequalities.

block1_text.eng: A kite is a 4-sided polygon that has two pairs of adjacent equal sides. It is also convex, like the blue figure on the left. The red figure on the right is called a dart because it is concave (it has an indentation).

block1_text.eng:
A line is a one-dimensional straight geometric object that extends infinitely in both directions. It can be thought of as an infinitely long straight wire that has no thickness.

There are three lines in this illustration – lines AB, CD, and EF. Note that if you only want to look at the parts of the lines between the red points, there are three line segments on those three lines – line segments AB, CD, and EF.

block1_text.eng:
There are several forms of symmetry. The symmetry referred to here is called **mirror symmetry.** A line of symmetry is a line superimposed on a flat image so that one side of the line is the reflection of the other side.

A picture of a human face will usually have a line of symmetry through the nose and chin. Some figures have many lines of symmetry. For example, a square has four lines of symmetry – two lines through pairs of opposite corners and two through pairs of midpoints of opposite sides.

block1_text.eng:
A line segment is a finite, connected portion of a line. It is the portion of a line that has two specified points as its endpoints.

The edges of a polygon are examples of line segments.

There are two line segments in this illustration. There is AC, the line segment between A and C. There is also the part of the line AB that goes only between A and B, and that is the line segment AB.

block1_text.eng:
Making tens can be an effective strategy for adding up a series of single-digit numbers. **Example:** Rearrange 2 + 7 + 3 + 5 + 8 in groups of 10 as
2 + 8 + 7 + 3 + 5 = 10 + 10 + 5 = 25.

block1_text.eng:
Math Talk has two meanings. 

One is that it refers to the practice of talking with children about the math that is all around us all the time. Doing Math Talk in this way is about developing the habit of verbalizing to your child the frequent mathematical thoughts an adult is already thinking. Studies have shown that doing Math Talk during ages 0 to 6 has a large impact on the math preparation of a child going into school.

The second meaning of math talk is a discussion held in a classroom centering on some mathematical concept. There are many kinds of these math talks, such as number talks, shape talks, and dot talks.

block1_text.eng:
The number bonds for a number are all the pairs of whole numbers that add up to it.

**Example:** The number bonds for 7 are 0 + 7, 1 + 6, 2 + 5, and 3 + 4.

Ten frames have many uses. One of them is to emphasize the number bonds for 10, which are particularly useful number bonds to learn.

A number line in the early years is a ray with evenly-spaced and labeled tic marks, with the labels starting at 0 and increasing in value as they move to the right. 

As the sophistication of the students increases, fractions can be added to the number line. When negative numbers are included, they are put to the left side of 0.

Give an overview of whole numbers, counting numbers, natural numbers, and integers. 
Positive numbers, negative numbers, non-negative numbers, and nonpositive numbers.

Perhaps include rational numbers, fractions, and decimals.

block1_text.eng: A numeral is the written form of a number. It usually consists of a sequence of digits that use place value in base 10 to give the numeral meaning.

block1_text.eng: A numerical expression is a representation of a quantity in numeric form. This representation may involve numbers, or operations. An example is: 42, x, (413 + 82) / 17. Another description of a numerical expression is that it is an expression that does not contain any variables.

An octagon is an eight-sided polygon. It is also a polygon with eight angles.

The red octagon on the left below has 8 equal sides and 8 equal angles, so it is a regular octagon – it is shaped like a stop sign. THe blue octagon on the right is not a regular octagon.

block1_text.eng:
An odd number is an integer that has a remainder of 1 when divided by 2. It is an integer that cannot be split into two equal integer parts.

For positive whole numbers, odd numbers are quantities of objects that cannot be shared evenly between between two groups without splitting some of the objects into fractional parts.

block1_text.eng:
Order of operations refers to the order in which terms should be combined in order to evaluate a mathematical expression.

In English, the expression PEMDAS is used to help students remember this order, though it should be renamed GEMDAS. The letters stand for:
* P = parentheses
* G = grouping symbols in general
* E = exponents
* M = multiplication
* D = division
* A = addition
* S = subtraction.

**Examples:**
* 2 + 3 x 5 = 2 + (3 x 5) = 17. The multiplication should be done first.
* 6 / 3 x 2 = (6 / 3) x 2 = 4. Work from left to right for operations of equal importance.
* Look at the dropdown items for many more examples.

block2_text.eng:
Grouping symbols, such as parentheses or square brackets, are given highest priority. The expression inside a grouping symbol is always evaluated first.

For example, (2 + 3) x 4 = 5 x 4 = 20.

Grouping also occurs when writing fractions with horizontal bars, and when using functional notation such as f(2 + 3).

block3_text.eng:
Exponent expressions are performed next. For example, 3 + 2<sup>4</sup> = 3 + 16 = 19. Similarly, 2<sup>4</sup> + 3 = 16 + 3 = 19. This is more useful to keep in mind when carets are used to denote exponentiation. For example 2^4+3 is 16 + 3 = 19 and not 2^(4 + 3) = 128. 

A common point of confusion occurs when writing and evaluating an exponent expression with a negative base. Because of PEMDAS, if you want to write -2 raised to the fourth power, you must write it as (-2)<sup>4</sup> = 16, and not as -2<sup>4</sup>, which would be -16.

Another difficulty can occur when there are two levels of exponents, such as in 2<sup>3<sup>2</sup></sup>. Because there are two expenents, the left to right rule says that this is (2<sup>3</sup>)<sup>2</sup> = 8<sup>2</sup> = 64. If carets are used instead to write it as 2^3^2, the applicability of the left to right rule becomes more obvious.

block4_text.eng: Multiplication and division are performed next. They are given equal priority (despite their relative positions in PEMDAS). When consecutive operations of equal priority are encountered, they are performed left to right. For example, 6 / 2 x 3 is equal to (6 / 2) x 3 = 9 and not equal to 6 / (2 x 3) = 1.

block5_text.eng: Addition and subtraction are performed last (including the opposite symbol "-"). These are given equal priority as well. Similar to mutiplication and division, when a string of consecutive additions and subtractions are encountered, they are evaluated from left to right. For example, 10 - 3 + 2 is (10 - 3) + 2 = 9 and not 10 - (3 + 2) = 5.

block6_text.eng: PEMDAS misleads some people into thinking muliplication has higher priority than division, and addition has higher priority than subtraction.. As described above, multiplication and division should be given equal priority, and addition and subtraction should also be given equal priority.

block1_text.eng:
A **cardinal number** is the count or size of a collection. This is in contrast to an **ordinal number,** which describes the relative position. 

**Example:** You might have the second in a collection of four objects - four is the cardinal number and second is the ordinal number.

See also: **numbers – types.**

rows.block1_text:

**Example:** You might have the second in a collection of four objects - four is the cardinal number and second is the ordinal number.

See also: **numbers – types.**

block1_text.eng:
Two infinite lines lying in a flat two-dimensional plane are parallel if they do not intersect. Two sides of a figure, such as the opposite sides of a rectangle, are said to be parallel if they are parts of two parallel lines.

In this illustration, lines AB and EF are horizontal lines, and they are parallel to each other. The line CD is a vertical line, and it is perpendicular to both line AB and line EF.

block1_text.eng: A parallelogram is a quadrilateral with two pairs of parallel sides. Squares, rectangles, and rhombuses are all quadrilaterals that are also parallelograms.

block1_text.eng:
Breaking a whole larger collection into a group of smaller parts is an important developmental step. It is an essentail step in learning beginning addition and subtraction. Seeiing a small group as a unit is called **unitiziing.**

**Example:** Seeing 7 things as being made up of two parts (or units) will help in understanding counting on, number bonds, addition, subtraction, and fact families. Going further, seeing 7 as being made up of the parts 3 and 4, which can be treated as individual units, will help greatly with understanding that 3 + 4 = 7, 4 + 3 = 7, 7 - 3 = 4, and 7 - 3 = 4 make up a fact family.

block1_text.eng:
A pattern is any rule that describes how to determine the items in a sequence or collection. **Repeating patterns,** ones where a short collection of items repeat over and over, are the simplest kinds of patterns.

Here is an example of a repeating pattern using shapes.

block2_text.eng:
Here is a simple repeating pattern using just colors: red, red, blue, red, red, blue, red, red, blue. 

However, there can be non-repeating patterns such as 2, 4, 6, 8, ..., which lists the even numbers, or 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, ..., which lists the prime numbers.

block1_text.eng: A pentagon is a five-sided polygon. It is also a polygon with five angles. All the sides are equal on the red pentagon on the left, it is a regular polygon. The blue pentagon on the right is not a regular pentagon.

block1_text.eng: The perimeter of a closed figure in the plane is the length of its boundary. The perimeter of a circle is its circumference. The perimeter of a polygon is the sum of the lengths of its sides.

rows.block1_text: The perimeter of a closed figure in the plane is the length of its boundary. The perimeter of a circle is its circumference. The perimeter of a polygon is the sum of the lengths of its sides.

block1_text.eng:
Two figures that are lines, line segments, or rays, are said to be perpendicular if they intersect and form a 90 degree angle.

In this illustration, lines AB and EF are horizontal lines, and they are parallel to each other. The line CD is a vertical line, and it is perpendicular to both line AB and line EF.

rows.block1_text:

In this illustration, lines AB and EF are horizontal lines, and they are parallel to each other. The line CD is a vertical line, and it is perpendicular to both line AB and line EF.

block1_text.eng:
When a sequence of digits is written as a numeral, that sequence has a value determined by the place value of each digit. Place value systems can use a variety of bases; however, base 10 is usually used and that is what we will assume here.

Use 704 as an example. Each digit in this numeral is given a value determined by its place in the numeral. The rightmost number, 4, is in the 1's place. Working right to left, the next number, 0, is in the 10's place. Finally, the leftmost number, 7, is in the 100's place. As you work from right to left, the value of each place increases by a factor of 10. We use a factor of 10 because this number is written in base 10. Finally, the value of 704 can be read off using the place values as 7 x 100 + 0 x 10 + 4 x 1. Another way to look at this is to use expanded form and write 704 as 700 + 0 + 4.

block1_text.eng: A plane is a two-dimensional geometric figure that extends infinitely in all the directions within the plane. Think of it as a table top or piece of paper that goes on forever. As a purely geometric object, planes have no thickness.

rows.block1_text: A plane is a two-dimensional geometric figure that extends infinitely in all the directions within the plane. Think of it as a table top or piece of paper that goes on forever. As a purely geometric object, planes have no thickness.

block1_text.eng: A plane figure is a geometric figure that is entirely contained within a plane. It is also called a two-dimensional figure.

rows.block1_text: A plane figure is a geometric figure that is entirely contained within a plane. It is also called a two-dimensional figure.

block1_text.eng: A point is a zero-dimensional geometric figure. A point denotes a location, but it has no depth, width, or length.

rows.block1_text: A point is a zero-dimensional geometric figure. A point denotes a location, but it has no depth, width, or length.

block1_text.eng: A polygon is a plane figure made up of a collection of straight sides (edges). The sides only intersect at their endpoints and each endpoint connects exactly two sides. This collection of sides creates a closed figure, which is the polygon.

rows.block1_text: A polygon is a plane figure made up of a collection of straight sides (edges). The sides only intersect at their endpoints and each endpoint connects exactly two sides. This collection of sides creates a closed figure, which is the polygon.

block1_text.eng:
Polygons are named by how many sides they have. The most common names are the following.

* **triangle** – 3 sided
* **quadrilateral** – 4 sided
* **pentagon** – 5 sided
* **hexagon** – 6 sided
* **octagon** - 8 sided

A polygon all of whose sides are equal is an **equilateral polygon.** A polygon all of whose angles are equal is an **equiangular polygon.** An equilateral, equiangular polygon is a **regular polygon.**

block1_text.eng: A polyhedron is a three-dimensional figure made up of a collection of polygons. The edges of the polygons are connected to exactly two polygons. These polygons form a closed figure, which is the polyhedron.

block1_text.eng:
A positive number is a number greater than 0. On a number line, positive numbers are to the right of 0.

See also **numbers – types.**

block1_text.eng:
Just as 4 × 2 is a quick way to write 2 + 2 + 2 + 2, so 2<sup>4</sup> is a quick way to write 2 × 2 × 2 × 2. It’s much easier to say and understand the phrase “two to the fourth,” than to say “two times two times ... “ In 2<sup>4</sup> for example, the 2 is called the **base** and the 4 is called the **exponent** or **power.**

**Special Names:** The second power, 4<sup>2</sup> for example, can be said **four squared,** and the third power, 4<sup>3</sup> for example, can be said **four cubed.** Any other power, such as 2<sup>8</sup> is said **two to the eighth.**

The phrase "8 is a power of 2" refers to 8 being the third power of 2. The first few powers of 2 are 2, 4, 8, and 16.

block1_text.eng:
Positive prime numbers are the numbers larger than 1 that are onlly divisible by 1 and themselves. The primes less than 20 are: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, and 19.

See **numbers – types.**

block1_text.eng:
A prism is a 3-dimenstional figure that has two parallel and identical faces called bases. All of its other faces are parallelograms.

A right prism is a prism where all of its sides that are not bases are rectangles.

Prisms are often named after the shape of their bases. For example, a right rectangular prism is another name for a box. A triangular prism is one that has bases that are triangles.

Though similar, a cylinder is not considered to be a prism.

See also **shapes – 3d.**

block1_text.eng: The product of two numbers is the result from multiplying them. For example, the product of 2 and 3 is 6.

rows.block1_text: The product of two numbers is the result from multiplying them. For example, the product of 2 and 3 is 6.

block1_text.eng:
The main properties of operations in beginning math are the commutative, associative, and distributive properties.

The **commutative property** says that an operation can be done in either order and give the same result (the name comes from moving around or commuting). Addition and multiplication have the commutative property, but subtraction and division do not. For example, 2 + 4 = 4 + 2; 2 x 4 = 4 x 2; 4 - 2 ≠ 2 - 4, and 4 / 2 ≠ 2 / 4.

The **associative property** says that an operation applied to three things will create the same result no matter which of the two possible groupings (associations) is used. Addition and multiplication satisfy the associative property, and subtraction and division do not. For example (2 + 3) + 7 = 5 + 7 = 12 and 2 + (3 + 7) = 2 + 10 = 12. Similarly, (2 x 3) x 7 = 6 x 7 = 42 and 2 x (3 x 7) = 2 x 21 = 42.

Multiplication is said to **distribute over** addition or subtraction. For example, (2 + 3) x 7 = 2 x 7 + 3 x 7. Similarly, putting the multiplication first, 7 x (3 -2) = 7 x 3 - 7 - 2. Division also distributes over addition or subtraction, but only on the right side. For example, (6 + 4) / 2 = 6 / 2 + 4 / 2 and (6 - 4) / 2 = 6 / 2 - 4 / 2.

See also: **associative property,** **commutative property,** and **distributive property.**

Similarly, (2 x 3) x 7 = 6 x 7 = 42 and 2 x (3 x 7) = 2 x 21 = 42.

Multiplication is said to **distribute over** addition or subtraction. For example, (2 + 3) x 7 = 2 x 7 + 3 x 7. Similarly, putting the multiplication first, 7 x (3 -2) = 7 x 3 - 7 - 2. Division also distributes over addition or subtraction, but only on the right side. For example, (6 + 4) / 2 = 6 / 2 + 4 / 2 and (6 - 4) / 2 = 6 / 2 - 4 / 2.

block1_text.eng:
A pyramid is a polyhedron with a polygonal base and sides which are triangles that all meet at a single point called its vertex. Pyramids are named after their base. For example, the pyramids in Egypt are square-based pyramids.

See also **shapes – 3d.**

block1_text.eng: A quadrilateral is a four-sided polygon. It is also a polygon with four angles.

rows.block1_text: A quadrilateral is a four-sided polygon. It is also a polygon with four angles.

block1_text.eng:
There are many types of quadrilaterals.

* **square** – it is equiangular and equilateral; it is a regular quadrilateral
* **rectangle** – It is equiangular, and all the angles are 90 degrees
* **rhombus** – it is equilateral; all the sides are the same length
* **parallelogram** – it has two pairs of parallel sides
* **trapezoid** or **trapezium** – it has exactly one pair of parallel sides
* **kite** – it has two pairs of adjacent, equal sides, and all its angles are less than 180 degrees (though some people do not add this angle restriction)
* **dart** – it has two pairs of adjacent, equal sides, and one of its angles is greater than 180 degrees.

A square is always a rectangle. A rectangle is always a parallelogram. A rhombus is always a parallelogram.

There are also many theorems about characteristics of their diagonals and how to calculate their areas.

block1_text.eng:
This word has two interpretations.

When it refers to a geometric figure, it is the name of a line segment that goes between the center of a circle and a point on the circle. Here is a circle with two radii drawn in.

block2_text.eng:
When it refers to a length, it is the length of any radius of a circle. This is well defined because any radius of a given circle has the same length.

The two interpretations are rarely confused because one is a number and the other is a geometric figure.

The plural of radius is radii.See also **shapes – 2d.**

A ray is a portion of a line that begins at one point on the line, the endpoint of the ray, and continues infinitely along the line in one of the two possible directions.

There are several rays in this illustration. There is the ray AC. There are also rays AB and BA that are part of the line AB.

block1_text.eng: Rectangles are four-sided polygons with four equal angles. Note that all squares are rectangles. Also, a rectangle with four equal sides is a square.

block2_text.eng:
Although not part of the definition, some properties of rectangles that follow from the definition are:
1. The angles are all 90 degree angles (like the angles at the corners of a piece of paper)
2. The opposite sides are parallel (they are parallelograms).
3. The opposite sides have the same length.
4. The diagonals have the same length.

See also **shapes – 2d.**

block1_text.eng: A rhombus is a quadrilateral with four equal sides. It can also be called an equilateral quadrilateral. A rhombus is always a parallelogram. A rhombus with right angles is a square.

block1_text.eng: A right angle is a 90 degree angle. Most pieces of paper and corners of rooms and buildings are right angles.

block1_text.eng:
Except for the circle, these shapes are all examples of polygons. A polygon with equal sides and equal angles is called a **regular polygon.**

* **Circle**
* **Triangle** – 3 sides and 3 angles
* **Rectangle** – 4 sides and 4 right angles (all equal of course)
* **Rhombus** – 4 equal sides and 4 angles
* **Square** – 4 equal sides and 4 right angles – it is both a rectangle and a rhombus.
* **Kite** – 4 sides with two pairs of equal and adjacent sides.
* **Pentagon** – 5 sides and 5 angles
* **Hexagon** – 6 sides and 6 angles
* **Octagon** – 8 sides and 8 angles

block1_text.eng:
These are the basic 3d shapes:

* **Ball** (**Sphere**)
* **Cylinder** (round tube with end caps)
* **Box** (**Cube**)
* **Pyramid** – triangle or square base
* **Cone**

The outside surface of a 3-dimensional shape is made up of 2-dimensional shapes.

* Ball / Sphere. This has one curved surface. If you were to cut the surface along its "equator" you would have two cups which you could flatten down to be two discs.
* Cylinder. Its ends are two discs. If you cut its curved surface with a straight cut from top to bottom it would be a rectangle.
* Box. This has 6 faces that are rectangles. 
* Triangular Pyramid. This has 4 faces that are triangles.
* Square Pyramid. This has 4 faces that are triangles and one face that is a square.
* Cone. This has a circle on the bottom. If you slit the curved surface from the point to the bottom you would have a portion of a disc.

block1_text.eng: Two objects are **similar** if they have the same shape. If two objects are similar, then one of them can be expanded or contracted to be exactly the same shape as the other.

block1_text.eng:
Skip counting means to counting skipping a set size of number gap starting a set beginning point. Skip counting by 1s is just the normal counting.

**Examples:**
* Skip counting by 2s starting at 5 – 5, 7, 9, 11, 13, 15..
* Skip counting by 10s starting at 30 – 30, 40 50, 60, 70.
* Skip counting by 2s going downward starting at 31 – 31, 29, 27, 25, 23.

Skip counting provides valuable practice of various kinds.
* Skip counting by 1s starting at a number, say 7, is Counting On from 7.
* Skip counting by Xs starting at a multiple of X, is practice with multiples of X and good preparation for multiplicaiton.
* Skip counting by Xs starting at any number going up or down provides simple and useful practice with single-digit addition and subtraction.
* Skip counting by Xs starting at any number is good practice for doing division with remainders.

block1_text.eng:
There are two mathematical meanings of **square.**

In geometry, a square is a quadrilateral with four equal sides and four equal angles. It is an equiangular and equilateral quadrilateral.

block2_text.eng:
See also **shapes – 2d.**

For numbers, a square is a number produced by multipyling a number times itself. 1, 4, 9, and 16 are square numbers.. The name “square” comes from these numbers being the area of a square. For example, 16 is the square of 4, and it is the area of a 4 by 4 square.

block1_text.eng: This term has various slightly different interprations. At the heart of them is the idea of instantly recognizing, without counting, small quantities. For example, being able to look at a dot pattern from one side of a die and immediately know how many dots there are.

block2_text.eng:
Studies have shown that human babies can instantly recognize quantities of size 1, 2, and 3. Above that, people subitize quantities by becoming familiar with the pattern of their presentation. 

For example, two rows of four objects can be subitized with a little practice. Once some patterns have been established, further patterns can be created from those. For example, two groups of 5 dots can be subitized as 10.

Practicing with subitizing is useful for learning unitizing and beginning addition and subtraction.

block1_text.eng: The sum of two numbers is the result of adding them. For example, the sum of 2 and 3 is 5.

block1_text.eng:
There are many types of symmetry.

The most common is mirror symmetry about a mirror line or mirror plane. If a figure has a line (or plane) for which the figure is unchanged when it is reflected about that line (or plane), then the figure is symmetrical about it.

block2_text.eng:
Another form of symmetry is called rotational symmetry. If a figure looks the same when it is rotated by a certain angle size about a point, then the figure is said to have rotatioinal symmetry about that point. 

**Example** Regular hexagons have 60 degree rotational symmetry about their central point.

block1_text.eng:
Take away is one of the two main models for subtraction (along with difference).

If you have 5 objects and 3 are removed, it is useful to model this as doing 5 take away 3, which is 5 - 3 = 2.

block1_text.eng:
A ten frame is a 2 by 5 array of empty boxes, often pictured horizontally. It is often partially filled with dots, and the filling typically fills the top row first from left to right. Ten frames are extremely useful for many early number concepts.

Ten frames form a familiar context for learning to subitize the quantities up to 10.

They are useful for learning the number bonds for 10. A child familiar with ten frames will see 7 dots in a ten frame and know immediately that 3 more dots are needed to make 10.

block1_text.eng: A three-dimensional figure usually refers to a geometric figure that cannot be contained in a single plane. Figures such as a cube, sphere, or cylinder are examples of three-dimensional figures.

block1_text.eng: A tiling of a shape is a covering of the shape with a repetition of a few basic shapes. Typically the types of tiles will be a limited collection of polygons, and the surface being tiled will be a flat, plane surface. A tiling can also be called a **tessellation.**

block2_text.eng: A regular tiling is one that has a single kind of tile that is a regular polygon. There are three types of these: all regular triangles, all squares, and all regular hexagons. The hexagons create the familiar honeycomb pattern. There are very large collection of beautiful non-regular tilings.

The hexagons create the familiar honeycomb pattern. There are very large collection of beautiful non-regular tilings.

block1_text.eng: A trapezoid is a quadrilateral with exactly one pair of parallel sides. It is also called a **trapezium.**

rows.block1_text: A trapezoid is a quadrilateral with exactly one pair of parallel sides. It is also called a **trapezium.**

block1_text.eng: See **trapezoid.**

rows.block1_text: See **trapezoid.**

block1_text.eng: A triangle is a three-sided polygon. It is also a polygon with three angles.

rows.block1_text: A triangle is a three-sided polygon. It is also a polygon with three angles.

block1_text.eng:
Triangles are usually described in terms of their side lengths or their angle measures.

Side lengths:
1. **Equilateral** – All three side lengths are the same. This also forces all angles to be 60 degrees. It is also a **regular triangle.**
2. **Isosceles** – Two side lengths are the same. This also forces two angles to be the same.
3. **Scalene** – No two side lengths are the same. This also forces that no two angles are the same.

Angle measures:
1. **Obtuse** – One angle is larger than 90 degrees (obtuse).
2. **Right** – One angle is equal to 90 degrees.
3. **Acute** – All three angles are less than 90 degrees (acute).
4. Two angles the same – This is an isosceles triangle with two equal sides.
5. **Equiangular** – All three angles are 60 degrees. It is also **equilateral** and **regular.**

A regular triangle is one that is both equangular and equilateral (which is what a regular polygon is for any number of sides). A triangle has three equal angles if and only if it has three equal sides. So, for triangles, being regular, equiangular, and equilateral are all the same.

A triangle has two equal angles if and only if it has two equal sides. Thus, an isosceles triangle could be defined as one that has two equal angles. However, given the name we use (which is a translation of "two equal sides"), the two equal sides definition is more natural.

block1_text.eng:
A triangular number is a number which is the sum of the first positive integers. It is called triangular becuase if you have that many dots the dots can be placed in a triangular pattern.

There are many basic geometric shapes that can be made with patterns of dots – rectangular, square, trapezoid – however, triangular is one of the most well known.

**Examples**
* 1
* 3 = 1 + 2
* 6 = 1 + 2 + 3
* 10 = 1 + 2 + 3 + 4

block1_text.eng: A two-dimensional figure is one that can be contained in a plane. A two-dimensional figure is also a plane figure.

rows.block1_text: A two-dimensional figure is one that can be contained in a plane. A two-dimensional figure is also a plane figure.

block1_text.eng:
1 is called a **unit,** and it is not a prime number. It is the only positive integer that is a unit.

Some people think that 1 is a prime because it is only divisible by 1 and itself. It is important to clear up this misconception.

block1_text.eng:
Unitizing is treating a group of objects as a unit. Being able to unitize is an important developmental step. Unitizing is central to understanding part-whole models, which then lead to better understandings of counting on, addition, subtraction, number bonds, and fact families. 

Unitizing is also central to understanding making bundles of 10 to understand place value. As in the illustration below, a student needs to see the columns of 10 boxes as units they can work with and not as a big collection of individual boxes.

block1_text.eng:
A Venn diagram is a model comprising a collection of overlapping circles or shapes. It is used to organize a collection of objects. Typically each shape in the diagram will hold the objects with a particular property or set of properties. Shapes in the diagram will overlap if there are objects that can belong inside both shapes.

For example, suppose you have a collection of wooden polygons. A Venn diagram might have two circles – one for triangles and one for red polygons. The red triangles would go inside the overlap of the two circles. The polygons that are not red and are not triangles would be placed outside both circles.

block1_text.eng:
The vertex of an angle is the point of intersection of the two sides of the angle. Similarly, a vertex of a polygon is a point where two of its sides intersect. A vertex for a polyhedron, or other various geometric figure, will be at the vertex point of an angle that is part of that figure.

The plural of vertex is vertices.

block1_text.eng:
A vertical geometric figure is one that goes straight up and down. A vertical line is perpendicular to a horizontal line.

In this illustration, lines AB and EF are horizontal lines, and they are parallel to each other. The line CD is a vertical line, and it is perpendicular to both line AB and line EF.

block1_text.eng:
The volume of a 3-dimensional object is a measure of the space enclosed by the object.

**Examples**
* Sphere – The volume is the product of 4/3 times the cube of its radius.
* Box – The volume is the lenght times the height times the width.
* Prism – The volume is the area of the base time the height (the distance between the bases).
* Cylinder – The volume is the area of the base time the height (the distance between the bases).

block1_text.eng:
Confusingly, some people consider whole numbers to be all the integers, and others feel these numbers should not include the negative integers. The first group justifies their definition by saying that whole numbers are all numbers with no fractional part.

See also: **numbers – types.**
